Comment: The real reason: who will compel them to do their job? Typically, if a politician is doing a bad enough job, only the voters are in charge of dismissing them.  The more generous reason: politicians often spend time between gathering with the rest of their peers and spending time back in their districts. In an ideal world they'd be able to vote safely and securely via remote access and spend all their time with their constituents, but most places don't have that set up (or have actively prohibited it).  Disallowing remote voting can be beneficial in that it allows shenanigans during times when the governing body is not meeting or when some members cannot attend for external reasons (ie calling a vote when everyone goes home). More generously, a lot of virtual systems are not as secure as you might want for government business.

Comment: Some aren't. For example, English councils automatically kick out councillors that miss meetings without a valid reason. There's a lot of reasons for politicians to not turn up that are perfectly valid, for example some have second jobs that contribute to society (e.g. doctors and dentists) that they have to do. In parliamentary systems MPs are also ministers and might be away on government duty. Some MPs serve in multiple roles that might clash (e.g. councillor, mayor, MEP or member of a regional legislature). Others have caring requirements where they might be caring for a parent, spouse or child that occasionally causes them to miss sessions. They also can serve in parliamentary delegations to foreign nations or as election observers. They also could be handling a constituency matter. Also, people can get sick, we're not machines. On summation: politicians do more than just show up to vote (some, like Sinn Feinn MPs don't even turn up to vote for ideological reasons)

Comment: A politician's job does not include campaigning. That's their job interview. We don't pay them to campaign, and that's not among my personal list of excusable absences. By your logic, a salesperson could miss an important sales meeting because they're working on their sales pitch. A senator is there to perform the direct duties of their office; and right at the top of that list is voting on legislation. It's the entire foundation of a republic that they are selected to cast our votes for us.   Of course, there are additional aspects to the job. They need to write legislation, debate, amend, discuss in a public forum, and inform their constituents what that legislation is all about. They need to determine a budget and appropriate money.   Campaigning is something that they do on their own time. It's not ok that they're neglecting their job in the interest of keeping that job.   We should not expect this sort of attitude from our subordinates. Real change is destructive, and it's long past time we started tearing down the system that put us here.
